title: Computer Vision | Log #001
text: Computer Vision refers to teaching machines to understand and extract information from images and video. There has been research dating back to 1960s to extract contextual information from a visual input and it is a good read for those who are interested. For now let’s stick to understanding the modern approach that started with the breakthrough in 2012. AlexNet introduced in 2012 used Convolutional Neural Networks to solve image recognition with a significantly higher accuracy.

title: Computer Vision | Log #001
text: Computer Vision refers to teaching machines to understand and extract information from images and video. There has been research dating back to 1960s to extract contextual information from a visual input and it is a good read for those who are interested. For now let’s stick to understanding the modern approach that started with the breakthrough in 2012. AlexNet introduced in 2012 used Convolutional Neural Networks to solve image recognition with a significantly higher accuracy.

title: Computer Vision | Log #001
text:
Computer Vision vs Image Processing
But before we get ahead of ourself, let’s understand what is the difference between traditional image processing and computer vision. Although they are related fields they differ in their approach and objectives.






Image Processing

Pixel level operations to manipulate and enhance images
Filtering, color adjustments, transformations
Works at lower level of abstraction with pixel-level features
Does not involve learning from data and less demanding



Computer Vision

Analysing image content and extract meaningful insights
Object Recognition, Segmentation, Tracking
Higher level of abstraction, analyzing contents of the image
Learning features and patterns from datasets and requires large resources

title: Computer Vision | Log #001
text:
Applications
Some of the main applications of computer vision are as follows:

Image Classification
Object Detection
Semantic Segmentation
Instance Segmentation
Pose Estimation
Face and Person Recognition
Image Restoration

title: Computer Vision | Log #001
text:
Challenges
There are many challenges in computer vision that we are yet to overcome such as accuiring accurate large datasets that are labelled, removing bias in datasets, choosing the right architecture for a model, real-time processing and optimizing the computational requirements, etc.
We will work on getting a deeper understanding into this field in the future blogs.

title: About
text:
I am a Data Scientist with over 5 years of experience in software engineering and have worked in a variety of roles, including Data Engineering, Sofware Development and Machine Learning.
I like to dive deep into topics that peak my interest and this blog will be a place to share my learnings. I was inspired from this blog by Dr. Rachel Thomas from FastAI to start documenting my learning. Here are some of my favorite parts of the blog:

The top advice I would give my younger self would be to start blogging sooner.


Helps you learn. Organizing knowledge always helps me synthesize my own ideas. One of the tests of whether you understand something is whether you can explain it to someone else. A blog post is a great way to do that.


You are best positioned to help people one step behind you.

I am hoping that this blog will keep me disciplined when the discomfort of learning new things becomes real.
